title-group.article-title: Free vibration of tapered isotropic rectangular plates

contrib-group.aff: Department of Aerospace Engineering and Applied Mechanics, Bengal Engineering and Science University, Shibpur, Howrah, India

author-notes.corresp: Mihir Chandra Manna, Department of Aerospace Engineering and Applied Mechanics, Bengal Engineering and Science University, Shibpur, Howrah–711 103, India Email: mcmbecdu@mailcity.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper, free vibration analysis of isotropic rectangular plates with linearly varying thickness in one direction has been investigated using a high-order triangular element. The first order shear deformation theory is used to include the effect of transverse shear deformation. The element has 18 nodes on the sides and six internal nodes. The geometry of element is expressed by three linear shape functions of area coordinates. The formulation is displacement-based. The element has 51 degrees-of-freedom, which can be reduced to 39 degrees-of-freedom by Guyan reduction, mass condensation, or eigenvalue economization scheme for the degrees-of-freedom associated with the internal nodes. Rotary inertia has been included in the consistent mass matrix. Numerical examples are presented to show the accuracy and convergence characteristics of the element. Isotropic plates with different thickness ratios (varies from 0.01 to 0.2), tapered ratios, aspect ratios and boundary conditions are analyzed. The results obtained by present element show a close agreement with the available published results. Some numerical results have been given as new results.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Plates and shells as well as structures made of plates and shells have wide applications in ships, aircraft, bridges, etc. A thorough study of their dynamic behavior and characteristics is essential to assess and use the full potential of plates and shells. It is worth mentioning in this context that the Finite Element Method (FEM) has been proved to be more versatile tool in engineering fields (Zienkiewicz and Taylor, 1988; Cook et al., 1989). The application of finite element started for plate bending analysis in the early sixties. A number of difficulties were faced when Kirchoff’s hypothesis was applied to analyze bending as well as free vibration of thin plates. These are mostly associated with the satisfaction of normal slope continuity on the interfaces between various elements. The above-mentioned slope continuity problem has been eliminated by applying the well known Reissner-Mindlin’s hypothesis for thick plates. In Reissner-Mindlin’s hypothesis the transverse displacement (w) and rotations of normal (θx and θy) are expressed as independent field variables. A large number of published works on plate vibration are available as may be seen by inspection of the excellent review articles by Leissa (1969, 1977a,b, 1981a,b, 1987a,b) and Liew et al. (1995) and other comprehensive works by Cheung and Zhou (2000), Dickinson and Blasio (1986), Leissa (1973), Liew et al. (1990), Lim et al. (1989), Yamada and Irie (1987) and Zhou et al. (2002). Also, a large number of triangular and quadrilateral finite elements were developed for the analysis of thin as well as thick plates among which isoparametric elements became more popular (Clough and Tocher, 1965; Batoz et al., 1980; Hrabok and Hrudey, 1984). Shear locking, stress extrapolation and spurious modes are some problems faced by these elements instead of having high elegancy. To avoid the above-mentioned problems a number of thick plate bending elements have been proposed by Batoz and Katili (1992), Petrolito (1989), Yuan and Miller (1989) and Zhongnian (1992) and others.

In the aeronautical field, a great interest has been seen for analysis of plates with variable thickness due to their utility in aircraft wings. Pulmano and Gupta (1976) investigated the frequency parameters of a linear elastic rectangular plate of varying thickness in one direction using the finite strip method. Mizusawa (1993) has used the collocation method with orthogonal polynomials for vibration analysis of rectangular plates of variable thickness. A set of simple two-dimensional polynomial functions is proposed by Liew and Lim (1993) as the admissible displacement function in the Rayleigh-Ritz energy approach for the free transverse vibration analysis of symmetric trapezoidal plates with linearly varying thickness while Liew et al. (1994) have used the variational principle of a minimum energy functional and the Ritz numerical procedure with the pb-2 global shape functions as the admissible displacement amplitude functions to study the free transverse vibratory response of a class of unsymmetric trapezoidal plates of variable thickness. The free vibrations of a wide range of tapered rectangular plates with an arbitrary number of intermediate line supports in one or two directions were investigated by Cheung and Zhou (1999). A new set of admissible functions was developed for analysis of tapered plates. Zhou (2002) studied the free vibrations of point-supported rectangular plates with variable thickness using the Rayleigh-Ritz method. Shufrin and Eisenberger (2006) applied first-order shear deformation plate theory of Mindlin and higher-order shear deformation plate theory of Reddy to plate analysis. They obtained the natural frequencies for elastic rectangular plates of variable thickness by using the extended Kantorovich method.

The present paper utilizes a triangular element with 18 nodes equidistantly placed on the sides and six nodes internal to it. The element has three degrees-of-freedom (w, θx, θy) at the three nodes on the vertices (nodes 1, 7 and 13), at six side nodes nearer to mid side nodes (nodes 3, 5, 9, 11, 15 and 17) and at three internal nodes (nodes 22–24), two degrees-of-freedom (θx, θy) at midpoint nodes (nodes 4, 10 and 16) and single degree-of-freedom (w) at the remaining nodes (nodes 2, 6, 8, 12, 14 and 18–21) to express the transverse displacement (w) and both θx, and θy by a fifth-order and fourth-order polynomials (one order less than the transverse displacement), respectively to avoid shear locking. The inter-element displacement (w, θx, and θy) continuity exists and hence, the element is compatible. The element used is a straight-sided triangle. In the proposed element the transverse displacement field (w) and both θx and θy are expressed by a fifth order polynomial and a fourth order polynomial respectively. The nodes are so placed on the sides and inside of the proposed element that the mass and rotary inertia for the internal nodes are negligible and the well known Guyan reduction scheme (1965) for the mass condensation is efficiently utilized to get highly accurate natural frequencies of rectangular plates with tapered thickness under different boundary conditions involving all possible combinations of clamped, simply supported and free edges.

sec.title: 2. Finite element formulation
sec.p:
The formulation is based on the Reissner-Mindlin plate theory. In this theory it is assumed that the transverse deflection of the plate is small compared to the plate thickness and the normals to the plate mid-surface which is taken as the reference plane remain straight but may not remain normal to the deformed mid-surface. A 24-node triangular element is used to develop the finite element analysis procedure. The element is shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Present element.

The coordinates of any point P (Figure 2) within the element with respect to the global co-ordinate system are given (Cook et al., 1989) by (1) where Li = Ai/A, i = 1, 2, 3 and A is the area of the triangular element. Figure 2.
Area coordinates.
Again, (2)

From equations. (1) and (2) we get,
where A=12[(x2y3-x3y2)+(x3y1-x1y3)+(x1y2-x2y1)]
ai = xj yk - xk yj, bi = yj - yk and ci = xk - xj where the parameters i, j and k follow cyclic order of 1, 2 and 3.

The transverse displacement (w) and the rotations (θx and θy) of the normal are chosen as the complete fifth-order and fourth-order polynomials of area coordinates (L1, L2, L3) respectively and are expressed as follows: (3) where (4) (5) where {α} is a (21 × 1) column vector and both {β} and {γ} are (15 × 1) column vectors.

As rotations of the normal θx and θy are independent variables and they are not derivatives of w, the effect of shear deformation can be easily incorporated as (Cook et al., 1989): (10) where ϕx and ϕy are average shear strain over the entire plate thickness and θx and θy are the total rotations of the normal.
The generalized stress-strain relationship may be expressed as (11)
In the above equation the generalized stress vector is (12)

The generalized strain vector {ε} in terms of displacement fields (Cook et al., 1989) is (13) and the rigidity matrix [C] is given by (14) where for isotropic materials C11= Et03(yδ0+1)3/{12b3(1−ν2)}, c12=ν C11, C22=C11, C33=(1−ν) C11/2, C44=Et0(yδ0+1)/{2k(1+ν)} and C55 = C44, k is the warping factor which is taken as π2/12, δ0 = (t1 - t0)/t0 and y =ordinate of the Gauss point (see Figure 3). Derivatives of [N¯θ] and [N¯w] with respect to the global coordinates can be presented in matrix form as

The matrices [Q1¯] and[Q3¯]are of order of (10 × 15) and the matrices [Q2¯] and [Q4¯] are of order of (15 × 21).

The matrix [B] can be written as:

Thus, the element stiffness matrix [K]e is given by (18)

Equation (18) can be depicted as:
where [ρ1]10×10=∫[L2¯]T[L2¯] dA and [ρ2]15×15=∫[L1¯]T[L1¯] dA.
Applying Gauss quadrature integration scheme [ρ1]and [ρ2] can be evaluated.
Finally the element stiffness matrix has got the following form: (19)

In a similar manner the element consistent mass matrix of an element can be derived explicitly using the above shape functions and can be expressed as (20) where t(y) = t0(yδ0 + 1)/b, y =ordinate of the Gauss point (see Figure 3), [ρ3]21×21=∫{t( y)}{L0¯}T{L0¯} dA and [ρ4]15×15=∫{t( y)}3{L1¯}T{L1¯} dA which can also be determined by using Gauss quadrature integration scheme. A 12-points integration scheme is chosen for both the bending and shear part of the stiffness matrix to apply the full integration scheme for the bending part and the reduced integration scheme for the shear part as the degree of precision of the bending part of stiffness matrix is six and that of the shear part of the stiffness matrix is eight.

Stiffness and mass matrices obtained from equations (19) and (20), respectively, are of the order of 51 by 51. These matrices have been reduced to the required matrices ([K]er and [M]er) of the order of 39 by 39 by applying Guyan reduction scheme (Guyan, 1965) for global assembly. The reduced element stiffness ([K]er) and element consistent mass ([M]er) matrices can be assembled into the following final form for free vibration: (21)

The above equation has been solved by the simultaneous iterative technique of Corr and Jennings (1976) as both the matrices [K] and [M] are symmetric, sparse and positive definite and this iteration technique has fast convergence rates and involves less computation after substitution of boundary conditions to get first few frequencies for the lower modes of the plate.

sec.title: 3.1. Patch test for constant bending moment, pure shear and twisting moment
sec.p:
For all the examples Poison’s ratio of the plate material is taken as 0.3 and the warping factor (k) is assumed to be 1.2. To show the convergence characteristics and robustness of the element developed in this paper a cantilever plate is considered (Figure 3). The plate extends to infinity in the positive and negative y directions and is clamped along the edge x = 0 i.e., along the y-axis. The plate is subjected to a uniformly distributed constant moment M per unit length at the edge x = a. Two types of mesh geometries are solved for the constant bending moment patch test. For the mesh geometry of Figure 3(a), the boundary conditions are w = 0 at nodes 7, 35, 41, 42, 44 and 45, θx = 0 at nodes 7, 35, 42, 43 and 44 and θy = 0 at nodes 7, 9, 10, 11, 13, 20, 21, 22, 24, 31, 32 33, 35, 42, 43 and 44. The boundary conditions and constant moment condition are similarly assigned for the mesh geometry of Figure 3(b). The non-dimensional transverse edge deflections (Et3w/Ma2) at the edge x = a are numerically matching with the exact solutions (5.46000) for different thickness ratios (t/h = 0.01, 0.1, 1.0, 10.0, 100.0 and 1000.0) as expected. The same plate and the same mesh geometries are utilized for shear patch test. In this case, a shear loading of V per unit length is applied on the edge x = a. Computed vertical displacements in non-dimensional form (Gtw/Va) at nodes 13, 19, 20, 22, 23 and 24 exactly agree with the elementary solutions including both shear and bending, and for shear only. The value of warping factor (k) is taken as unity for this example to correspond to the elementary solution and to simulate the effect of pure shear, the terms in the rigidity matrix corresponding to the bending stiffness are multiplied by a large quantity. For twisting patch test the plate geometry is shown in Figure 4(a). The Young’s modulus of the plate material is taken as 10000 psi and the plate thickness is 1 inch. The plate is simply supported at points A, B and C (w = 0) and is subjected to a transverse load of 5 lb at D. The terms C44 and C55 in the rigidity matrix are multiplied by a large number (106). The plate is solved for the mesh divisions as shown in Figures 3(a), 3(b), 4(b), 4(c), 4(d) and 4(e). The deflections at point O and D and the moments are compared with thin plate solutions and other available published results (Table 1). Table 1.

sec.title: 4. Conclusions
sec.p: A 24-node triangular plate bending element with 51 degrees-of-freedom has been utilized to investigate the free vibration of isotropic rectangular plates with different thickness ratios, tapered ratios, aspect ratios and boundary conditions. The degrees-of-freedom associated with the six internal nodes are condensed by Guyan reduction scheme to get the reduced element stiffness and mass matrices of the order of 39 by 39.

Considering different mesh divisions (4 × 4, 8 × 8 and 12 × 12) a comparative study of present results with those of earlier investigators shows the rapid convergence characteristics and accuracy of the present element for very thin to thick plates. It can also be concluded that the increase in node numbers on the edges of the proposed element helps the mass and rotary inertia distribution at different nodes in such a way that the mass as well as rotary inertia associated with the internal nodes are negligible compared to those with the nodes on the edges. This helps the application of Guyan reduction scheme to this element efficiently and accurately.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
